bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, October 4, 1930

div1.p: Carter expresses her joy that the manuscript is being sent to the publisher and conveys her gratitude to Frost for his labor of love.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, October 4, 1930
div1.opener:
Book
Frost.
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
October 4, 1930.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
It was a beautiful thought of Susan's to call me up
and tell me that you were sending the MS of Father's book to
Colonel Russell to-day!

And it is a beautiful Thing that you have done: In
raising his failing torch and bearing it--once more aloft and
brightly burning!--to the goal which, though glimpsed, had
never been attained without you! I realize to the full all
that you have given to the book: of time, of genius--of
yourself! Indeed, I had never been willing to accept such
sacrifices as you and yours have made during the completion
of the book merely as a “labor of love” for Father. Nor do
I believe that you would (or should) have beenfelt justified in
thus making them. It is because I realize that the book was
completed, as it was begun, primarily “for the very work's
sake” that I am so willingly and completely your debtor.

Miss Brown, whom I could not forbear calling up at
the Library of Congress to tell the good news, sends felici-
tations and best remembrances to yourself and Susan and shares
in the deep thankfulness we all feel to-day.

My heart is too full for words, which would at best
be inadequate to thank you. God bless you, Jack! Truly you
have “wrought a goode worke!”

closer.seg:
Oct. 6/30
Sorry for the delay in getting this off, the result
of several attacks of dizziness, which, while not painful, are
distressing and (worse!) compel me to “slow up” when I am
most anxious not to.
L.A.C.
